source.title: Managing forest fuels for community protection in the interior of British Columbia: productivities and costs of thinning from below
source.site: Knife Creek block (3.8 ha) adjacent to Green Valley Estates, south of Williams Lake, BC (IDFxm). Winter 2005 thinning-from-below fuel treatment.

treatment.objective: Reduce ladder fuels and remove beetle-killed/danger trees while retaining saplings/poles for mule deer winter range.

phases.name: manual_falling
phases.notes: Chainsaw falling with wedges/peavey; trees debarked at stump to limit saw dulling from road dust.

phases.name: skidding_ford_tractor
phases.equipment: Ford 1725 tractor with Farmi winch + custom grapple
phases.notes: Primary machine for decking/piling plus medium-piece skidding.

phases.name: skidding_jd540
phases.notes: Used for occasional heavy turns; 19.4 min average cycle (detailed timing).

phases.name: skidding_honda_atv
phases.notes: Focused on bundles of slash/non-merchantable material once manually re-piled.

phases.name: manual_piling
phases.notes: Crew raked/piled residual slash in-stand prior to burning.

phases.name: burning_and_repiling
phases.notes: Propane tiger torch + leaf blower ignition; burning delayed to spring for venting; includes mechanical re-pile with tractor.

honda_atv.notes: Fast travel (~130 m/min) but extra time spotting loads increased maneuver share to 25%.

john_deere_540.notes: Handled large bunches; hook+winch comprised 34% of cycle.

usage_notes: Represents low-volume fuel-reduction thinning where manual work and debris handling dominate costs. Use as partial-cut penalty reference when modelling interface treatments requiring extensive piling/burning and mixed skidding equipment.
